bookstack.eli5: BookStack is like a digital bookshelf where you write and organize your own books and notes.
bookstack.boss: BookStack is a self-hosted wiki platform designed for organizing and sharing documentation in a book-like format.
bookstack.sysadmin: BookStack is a PHP-based documentation platform using MySQL and Laravel, structured with books, chapters, and pages.
bookstack.use_case: Used to maintain internal documentation and SOPs for a home lab or small business.

wiki_js.eli5: Wiki.js is like a super-powered notebook for teams that you can share and build together online.
wiki_js.boss: Wiki.js is an open-source, modern, and extensible wiki platform built for team collaboration.
wiki_js.sysadmin: Wiki.js is a Node.js-based knowledge management system with Git, Markdown, authentication, and multi-backend support.
wiki_js.use_case: Used by dev teams to write shared project documentation synced with GitHub.

hedgedoc.eli5: HedgeDoc is like a live whiteboard where people can write notes together at the same time.
hedgedoc.boss: HedgeDoc is an open-source collaborative Markdown editor for real-time document writing and note-taking.
hedgedoc.sysadmin: HedgeDoc provides Etherpad-like collaborative editing with Markdown syntax, share links, and Docker deployment support.
hedgedoc.use_case: Used during team meetings to take shared notes in real time.

joplin_server.eli5: Joplin Server is like your own private notebook you can take anywhere and keep safe at home.
joplin_server.boss: Joplin Server is the self-hosted backend for syncing notes with the Joplin app across multiple devices.
joplin_server.sysadmin: Joplin Server enables encrypted syncing for Joplin’s open-source note app via REST API and supports Docker-based installs.
joplin_server.use_case: Used to keep personal notes in sync between desktop and mobile via a home server.

infrastructure.eli5: Infrastructure is all the tech stuff like wires, computers, and networks that make the internet work.
infrastructure.boss: Infrastructure refers to the foundational hardware, software, and networks that support IT systems and services.
infrastructure.sysadmin: IT infrastructure includes servers, virtualization, networking, storage, power, and cooling systems required for deploying and maintaining applications.
infrastructure.use_case: Used to describe the full stack behind hosting a website, from data centers to DNS.

it_infrastructure.eli5: It’s like all the pipes and power lines behind a building, but for computers.
it_infrastructure.boss: IT infrastructure includes the physical and virtual resources that support an organization's IT environment.
it_infrastructure.sysadmin: IT infrastructure encompasses hardware, software, networking, storage systems, and services required to run enterprise-level IT workloads.
it_infrastructure.use_case: Used by companies to build scalable and secure platforms for business applications.

infrastructure_as_code_iac.eli5: It’s like writing a recipe to build your computer setup over and over without missing a step.
infrastructure_as_code_iac.boss: IaC is a method of managing infrastructure using code to automate provisioning and configuration.
infrastructure_as_code_iac.sysadmin: Infrastructure as Code (IaC) allows declarative or imperative scripts (e.g., Terraform, Ansible) to define and deploy infrastructure repeatedly and reliably.
infrastructure_as_code_iac.use_case: Used to provision cloud servers and networking automatically via Git.

bare_metal.eli5: Bare metal is like using a computer with nothing in between—you’re the boss.
bare_metal.boss: Bare metal refers to running operating systems directly on physical hardware without virtualization.
bare_metal.sysadmin: Bare metal servers offer full access to hardware resources without a hypervisor, ideal for performance-critical applications.
bare_metal.use_case: Used in high-performance workloads like databases or hypervisor hosts.

virtualization.eli5: Virtualization is like having many pretend computers running inside one real computer.
virtualization.boss: Virtualization allows multiple virtual machines to run on a single physical server, improving efficiency and scalability.
virtualization.sysadmin: Virtualization abstracts hardware via hypervisors (Type 1 or 2), enabling multiple isolated OS instances on a single host.
virtualization.use_case: Used to run several different servers on a single powerful host machine.

hypervisor.eli5: A hypervisor is like a boss that makes sure all the pretend computers play nice on the real one.
hypervisor.boss: A hypervisor is software that runs and manages virtual machines on physical hardware.
hypervisor.sysadmin: Hypervisors come in two types: Type 1 runs directly on hardware, while Type 2 runs on an OS. They manage VM resources and isolation.
hypervisor.use_case: Used to host multiple VMs for testing and production on the same server.
